contentHTML:
HSC BiologyFoundational

Prokaryotic vs Eukaryotic Cells: Evolution of Complexity

Discover the fundamental divide in cellular life: how membrane-bound organelles transformed simple prokaryotes into complex eukaryotes, enabling all multicellular life on Earth including humans.

ü¶†

üéØ LEARNING INTENTIONS

  • Students can distinguish between prokaryotic and eukaryotic cell structures
  • Students can identify membrane-bound organelles and explain their functions
  • Students can explain the evolutionary significance of compartmentalisation
  • Students can evaluate evidence for the endosymbiotic theory
  • Students can apply understanding to classify organisms by cell type

üîó KEY CONNECTIONS

  • Prior: Cell theory and basic cell structure
  • Future: Endosymbiotic theory, cellular respiration, photosynthesis
  • Real World: Antibiotic resistance in bacteria, human diseases caused by organelle dysfunction
  • Timeline: Prokaryotes 3.5 billion years ago ‚Üí Eukaryotes 2 billion years ago

‚úÖ SUCCESS CRITERIA

  • I can accurately label prokaryotic and eukaryotic cell diagrams
  • I can list at least 5 structural differences between cell types
  • I can explain three advantages of membrane-bound organelles
  • I can describe evidence supporting endosymbiotic theory
  • I can compare cell size and complexity using data
üî¨

The Fundamental Divide in Cellular Life

All living organisms are made of cells, but cells come in two fundamentally different forms. The presence or absence of membrane-bound organelles divides all life into two domains: prokaryotes and eukaryotes.

Cell TypeEtymologyDefining FeatureOrganisms
ProkaryoticGreek: pro = before, karyon = nucleusNo membrane-bound nucleus or organellesBacteria, Archaea
EukaryoticGreek: eu = true, karyon = nucleusMembrane-bound nucleus and organellesAnimals, plants, fungi, protists
üí° Key Concept: The presence of membrane-bound organelles is the single most important distinction in cell biology. This difference affects DNA storage, energy production, protein synthesis location, and cell size limits.
üß¨

Prokaryotic Cells: Simple but Successful

Prokaryotic cells are typically 0.1‚Äì5 Œºm in diameter, making them much smaller than eukaryotic cells. Despite their structural simplicity, they are incredibly diverse and successful, inhabiting every environment on Earth from Antarctic ice to volcanic hot springs.

StructureDescriptionFunction
Cell wallRigid outer layer (peptidoglycan in bacteria)Protection, shape maintenance, prevents bursting
Cell membranePhospholipid bilayerControls substance movement, site of respiration
Nucleoid regionCircular DNA in cytoplasm (not membrane-enclosed)Stores genetic information
Ribosomes70S ribosomes (smaller than eukaryotic 80S)Protein synthesis
PlasmidsSmall circular DNA molecules (optional)Carry extra genes (e.g. antibiotic resistance)
FlagellaLong whip-like structures (some species)Movement through liquid environments
PiliShort hair-like projectionsAttachment to surfaces, DNA transfer
‚ö†Ô∏è Common Mistake: Students often think prokaryotes lack DNA. Incorrect! Prokaryotes have DNA; it's just not enclosed in a membrane-bound nucleus. The DNA is located in the nucleoid region of the cytoplasm.
üß´

Eukaryotic Cells: Compartmentalised Complexity

Eukaryotic cells are typically 10‚Äì100 Œºm in diameter‚Äîup to 10 times larger than prokaryotic cells. Their defining feature is compartmentalisation: specialised membrane-bound organelles carry out specific functions in isolated environments.

OrganelleMembrane-Bound?FunctionPresent In
Nucleus‚úÖ YES (double membrane)Stores DNA, controls cell activitiesAll eukaryotes
Mitochondria‚úÖ YES (double membrane)Cellular respiration, ATP productionAll eukaryotes
Endoplasmic reticulum‚úÖ YESProtein and lipid synthesis, transportAll eukaryotes
Golgi apparatus‚úÖ YESProcesses and packages proteinsAll eukaryotes
Lysosomes‚úÖ YESDigests waste and old organellesAnimal cells mainly
Chloroplasts‚úÖ YES (double membrane)PhotosynthesisPlant cells, algae
Vacuole‚úÖ YESStorage of water, nutrients, wastePlant cells (large), animal cells (small)
Ribosomes‚ùå NOProtein synthesis (80S, larger than prokaryotic)All eukaryotes
Cytoskeleton‚ùå NOStructural support, intracellular transportAll eukaryotes
üí° Compartmentalisation Advantage: Membrane-bound organelles allow incompatible chemical reactions to occur simultaneously in different cellular locations. For example, protein synthesis (ribosomes in cytoplasm) and protein degradation (lysosomes) happen concurrently without interference.
üìä

Direct Comparison: Prokaryotic vs Eukaryotic

Understanding the differences between these cell types is fundamental to biology. This comparison table summarises the key structural and functional distinctions.

FeatureProkaryotic CellsEukaryotic Cells
Typical size0.1‚Äì5 Œºm10‚Äì100 Œºm
Nucleus‚ùå No true nucleus (nucleoid region)‚úÖ Membrane-bound nucleus with nuclear envelope
DNA organisationSingle circular chromosome, no histonesMultiple linear chromosomes with histone proteins
Membrane-bound organelles‚ùå Absent‚úÖ Present (mitochondria, ER, Golgi, lysosomes, etc.)
Ribosomes70S (smaller)80S (larger)
Cell wallPresent (peptidoglycan in bacteria)Present in plants/fungi (cellulose/chitin), absent in animals
Cell divisionBinary fission (simpler, asexual)Mitosis/meiosis (complex, sexual reproduction possible)
Metabolic diversityExtremely diverse (anaerobic and aerobic pathways)Less diverse (mostly aerobic respiration/photosynthesis)
MulticellularityRare (mostly unicellular, some colonies)Common (all complex multicellular organisms)
CytoskeletonSimple or absentComplex network of protein filaments
‚ö†Ô∏è Exam Trap: Ribosomes are present in BOTH cell types! The difference is size: prokaryotes have 70S ribosomes, eukaryotes have 80S ribosomes. Don't say 'eukaryotes have ribosomes, prokaryotes don't'‚Äîthis loses marks.
üåç

Evolutionary Significance of Membrane-Bound Organelles

The evolution of membrane-bound organelles approximately 2 billion years ago was one of the most important events in the history of life. This innovation enabled dramatic increases in cell size, complexity, and ultimately the emergence of all multicellular organisms.

Why Compartmentalisation Changed Everything

üî¨

1. SEPARATION OF INCOMPATIBLE PROCESSES

Destructive enzymes can be isolated from sensitive cellular components

Example: Lysosomes contain powerful digestive enzymes that would destroy the cell if not membrane-enclosed. The lysosomal membrane keeps these enzymes safely contained.
‚Üì
‚ö°

2. OPTIMISED MICROENVIRONMENTS

Each organelle maintains ideal conditions for its specific reactions

Example: Mitochondria maintain a low pH across their inner membrane to drive ATP synthesis. The cytoplasm maintains a different pH for other reactions.
‚Üì
üéØ

3. SPECIALISATION AND EFFICIENCY

Organelles evolve specialised structures and functions

Example: The highly folded inner membrane of mitochondria (cristae) increases surface area for ATP production by 5‚Äì10 times compared to a smooth membrane.
‚Üì
üß¨

4. COMPLEX MULTICELLULAR LIFE BECOMES POSSIBLE

Cell specialisation and coordination enable tissue and organ formation

Result: All multicellular organisms (animals, plants, fungi) are eukaryotic. Prokaryotes remain mostly unicellular.
üí° Size Advantage: Eukaryotic cells can be much larger than prokaryotic cells because compartmentalisation solves the problem of diffusion limits. Without organelles, a large cell would be too inefficient‚Äînutrients couldn't reach the centre fast enough, and waste products would accumulate.
üîÑ

Endosymbiotic Theory: How Organelles Evolved

The most widely accepted explanation for the origin of mitochondria and chloroplasts is the endosymbiotic theory, proposed by Lynn Margulis in 1967. This theory revolutionised our understanding of cellular evolution.

üí° Endosymbiotic Theory: Mitochondria and chloroplasts were once free-living prokaryotic cells that were engulfed by a larger host cell approximately 2 billion years ago. Instead of being digested, they formed a mutually beneficial (symbiotic) relationship. Over millions of years, they became permanent, essential organelles, losing the ability to live independently.

The Endosymbiotic Process

üìù How Endosymbiosis Created Mitochondria

Step 1: A large anaerobic prokaryote engulfs a smaller aerobic prokaryote (ancestor of mitochondria, likely an alpha-proteobacterium) through endocytosis.
Step 2: The small cell is not digested. Instead, it survives inside the host cell, enclosed by a membrane vesicle.
Step 3: The engulfed cell continues performing aerobic respiration, producing ATP. The host cell benefits from this energy supply.
Step 4: Over millions of years, the relationship becomes obligate‚Äîneither can survive without the other. Many genes transfer from the endosymbiont to the host nucleus.
Result: The engulfed cell becomes a mitochondrion with a double membrane (inner from original cell, outer from host vesicle), its own DNA, and 70S ribosomes.

Six Lines of Evidence for Endosymbiotic Theory

EvidenceObservationWhy It Supports the Theory
1. Double membraneMitochondria and chloroplasts have two membranesInner membrane from original prokaryote; outer membrane from host cell's engulfing vesicle
2. Own DNABoth organelles contain small, circular DNA moleculesCircular DNA is characteristic of prokaryotes, not eukaryotic nuclear DNA (which is linear)
3. 70S ribosomesTheir ribosomes are 70S, not 80S70S ribosomes are prokaryotic; eukaryotic cytoplasmic ribosomes are 80S
4. Independent replicationThey divide by binary fission, independently of cell divisionBinary fission is how prokaryotes reproduce, not how eukaryotic organelles typically replicate
5. Comparable sizeSize (~1‚Äì10 Œºm) similar to modern bacteriaMatches the expected size of ancestral prokaryotes
6. DNA sequence similarityMitochondrial DNA resembles alpha-proteobacteria; chloroplast DNA resembles cyanobacteriaMolecular phylogeny directly links organelles to specific groups of modern bacteria
üö´ Exam Trap: The double membrane does NOT mean 'two cell membranes from two cells'. The inner membrane is from the original prokaryote. The outer membrane is from the host cell's vesicle that engulfed it. This distinction is critical for exam answers.
‚ö†Ô∏è Timeline Context: Prokaryotic cells appeared ~3.5 billion years ago. Eukaryotic cells evolved ~2 billion years ago through endosymbiosis. This 1.5-billion-year gap represents the time prokaryotes dominated Earth before the evolutionary leap to cellular complexity occurred.

üìã COPY INTO YOUR BOOKS

Prokaryotic Cells

  • No membrane-bound nucleus (nucleoid region instead)
  • No membrane-bound organelles
  • Single circular chromosome, no histones
  • 70S ribosomes (smaller)
  • Size: 0.1‚Äì5 Œºm
  • Examples: Bacteria, Archaea

Eukaryotic Cells

  • Membrane-bound nucleus with DNA
  • Multiple membrane-bound organelles
  • Linear chromosomes with histone proteins
  • 80S ribosomes (larger)
  • Size: 10‚Äì100 Œºm
  • Examples: Animals, plants, fungi, protists

Key Membrane-Bound Organelles

  • Nucleus: stores DNA, controls cell
  • Mitochondria: cellular respiration, ATP
  • Endoplasmic reticulum: protein/lipid synthesis
  • Golgi apparatus: processes proteins
  • Lysosomes: digestion of waste
  • Chloroplasts (plants): photosynthesis

Endosymbiotic Theory Evidence

  • Double membrane structure
  • Own circular DNA (like bacteria)
  • 70S ribosomes (prokaryotic type)
  • Binary fission reproduction
  • DNA similarity to modern bacteria
  • Enabled evolution of complex life ~2 billion years ago
ACTIVITY 01

Diagram Comparison Task

Draw and label prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells, identifying structural differences.

In your books, draw a prokaryotic cell (e.g. bacterium) and a eukaryotic cell (e.g. animal cell) side by side. Label at least 5 structures in each. Circle or star the features that are ONLY found in eukaryotic cells.

  1. Draw both cells to scale (eukaryotic should be noticeably larger‚Äîat least 5√ó larger).
  2. Label prokaryotic cell: cell wall, cell membrane, nucleoid region, ribosomes, plasmid (optional), flagellum (optional).
  3. Label eukaryotic cell: nucleus, mitochondria, ER, Golgi apparatus, lysosomes, ribosomes.
  4. Write three key differences in a table below your diagrams.
ACTIVITY 02

Endosymbiotic Evidence Analysis

Evaluate the strength of evidence supporting endosymbiotic theory.

Complete the table below by explaining how each piece of evidence supports the idea that mitochondria and chloroplasts were once independent prokaryotic cells.

EvidenceHow It Supports Endosymbiotic Theory
Double membrane
Circular DNA
70S ribosomes
Binary fission
ACTIVITY 03

Graphing Task: Cell Size Comparison

Construct and interpret a graph comparing average cell sizes across different organisms.

Use the data below to create a bar graph comparing the average diameter of different cell types. Then answer the analysis questions.

Cell TypeAverage Diameter (Œºm)
Typical bacterium (prokaryotic)2
Human red blood cell (eukaryotic)8
Typical animal cell (eukaryotic)25
Typical plant cell (eukaryotic)50
  1. Draw a bar graph with cell type on the x-axis and diameter (Œºm) on the y-axis. Use appropriate scale and labels.
  2. Calculate: How many times larger is a typical animal cell compared to a bacterium?
  3. Explain why eukaryotic cells can be much larger than prokaryotic cells. Reference organelles and diffusion in your answer.
ACTIVITY 04

Evolutionary Timeline Analysis

Analyse the significance of the prokaryote-to-eukaryote transition in Earth's history.

Prokaryotic cells appeared approximately 3.5 billion years ago. Eukaryotic cells evolved approximately 2 billion years ago. Multicellular organisms appeared approximately 1 billion years ago.

  1. Calculate the time gap between the emergence of prokaryotic cells and eukaryotic cells.
  2. Suggest why it took so long (1.5 billion years) for eukaryotic cells to evolve from prokaryotic ancestors.
  3. Explain why multicellular life only evolved after eukaryotic cells appeared. What features of eukaryotic cells enabled the evolution of multicellularity?
‚ùì

Assessment Questions

Multiple Choice 5 MARKS

1. Which feature is found in eukaryotic cells but NOT in prokaryotic cells?

A
DNA
B
Ribosomes
C
Membrane-bound nucleus
D
Cell membrane

2. Which group consists entirely of prokaryotic organisms?

A
Plants and fungi
B
Animals and protists
C
Bacteria and archaea
D
Fungi and bacteria

3. Which statement about mitochondria provides the STRONGEST evidence for endosymbiotic theory?

A
Mitochondria are found in all eukaryotic cells.
B
Mitochondria produce ATP through cellular respiration.
C
Mitochondria have their own circular DNA and 70S ribosomes, like bacteria.
D
Mitochondria are larger than prokaryotic cells.

4. What is a major advantage of compartmentalisation in eukaryotic cells?

A
It makes cells smaller and more efficient.
B
It allows incompatible chemical processes to occur simultaneously in different locations.
C
It eliminates the need for DNA replication.
D
It prevents cells from dividing.

5. Approximately when did eukaryotic cells first evolve?

A
3.5 billion years ago
B
2 billion years ago
C
1 billion years ago
D
500 million years ago

Short Answer 12 MARKS

6. List and explain three structural differences between prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells. 3 MARKS

7. Describe the endosymbiotic theory for the origin of mitochondria. Include two pieces of evidence that support this theory. 4 MARKS

8. Explain two advantages that membrane-bound organelles provide to eukaryotic cells. Use specific examples of organelles in your answer. 5 MARKS

‚úÖ

Comprehensive Answers

üéØ ACTIVITY 01 ‚Äî Diagram Comparison

Diagram requirements: Prokaryotic cell should show cell wall, cell membrane, nucleoid region (circular DNA), ribosomes, and optionally plasmids and flagella. Eukaryotic cell should show nucleus, nuclear membrane, mitochondria, endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi apparatus, lysosomes, and ribosomes. Eukaryotic cell should be drawn 5‚Äì10 times larger than prokaryotic cell.

Features unique to eukaryotes to circle: Nucleus, mitochondria, ER, Golgi apparatus, lysosomes, any membrane-bound organelle.

Three key differences: (1) Eukaryotes have membrane-bound nucleus, prokaryotes have nucleoid region; (2) Eukaryotes have membrane-bound organelles, prokaryotes do not; (3) Eukaryotes are typically 10‚Äì100 Œºm, prokaryotes are 0.1‚Äì5 Œºm.

üéØ ACTIVITY 02 ‚Äî Endosymbiotic Evidence

Double membrane: The inner membrane came from the original prokaryotic cell that was engulfed. The outer membrane came from the host cell's vesicle that surrounded it during endocytosis. This two-layer structure matches what we'd expect if a cell was engulfed and retained.

Circular DNA: Prokaryotes have circular chromosomes, while eukaryotic nuclear DNA is linear. Mitochondria and chloroplasts having circular DNA suggests they descended from prokaryotic ancestors that had this DNA structure.

70S ribosomes: Prokaryotic cells have 70S ribosomes, while eukaryotic cytoplasmic ribosomes are 80S (larger). The fact that mitochondria and chloroplasts have 70S ribosomes links them directly to prokaryotic origins, not eukaryotic cell components.

Binary fission: These organelles divide by binary fission, the same method bacteria use to reproduce. This is different from how most eukaryotic organelles replicate, suggesting these organelles retain their prokaryotic reproductive mechanism from their ancestral free-living state.

üéØ ACTIVITY 03 ‚Äî Cell Size Graphing

Graph: Should show bacterium (2 Œºm), human RBC (8 Œºm), animal cell (25 Œºm), plant cell (50 Œºm) as bars with clearly labelled axes and appropriate scale.

Calculation: Animal cell (25 Œºm) √∑ bacterium (2 Œºm) = 12.5 times larger.

Explanation: Eukaryotic cells can be much larger because membrane-bound organelles solve the diffusion problem that limits prokaryotic cell size. In prokaryotes, all materials must diffuse through the cytoplasm‚Äîthe larger the cell, the slower this becomes, limiting efficiency. Eukaryotes compartmentalise functions: mitochondria concentrate energy production, the ER handles protein synthesis in dedicated regions, and the nucleus protects DNA. This organisation allows materials to be processed locally without needing to diffuse across the entire cell, enabling much larger cell sizes while maintaining efficiency.

üéØ ACTIVITY 04 ‚Äî Evolutionary Timeline

1. Time gap: 3.5 billion years ‚Äì 2 billion years = 1.5 billion years between prokaryotic and eukaryotic cell emergence.

2. Why so long: Endosymbiosis was an extremely rare, complex event. It required: (a) one cell to successfully engulf another without digesting it‚Äîmost attempts would have failed; (b) the establishment of a stable, mutually beneficial relationship over many generations; (c) specific environmental conditions, such as increasing atmospheric oxygen from cyanobacteria, which made aerobic respiration advantageous; (d) genetic integration, with many genes transferring from the endosymbiont to the host nucleus. Each of these steps was improbable, making the overall process extraordinarily unlikely and time-consuming.

3. Why multicellularity requires eukaryotes: Multicellular organisms need cells to specialise and communicate effectively. Eukaryotic cells have the necessary machinery: (a) membrane-bound organelles allow different cells to specialise for different functions (e.g. nerve cells with extensive ER for neurotransmitter production, muscle cells packed with mitochondria); (b) cytoskeleton provides structure, enables cell shape changes, and facilitates intracellular transport for signalling; (c) ability to produce extracellular matrices and adhesion proteins to hold cells together; (d) complex gene regulation systems involving the nucleus enable precise control of cell differentiation. Prokaryotic cells lack this organisational complexity, limiting them to mostly unicellular life (though some form simple colonies).

‚ùì MULTIPLE CHOICE

1. C ‚Äî Membrane-bound nucleus. Option A (DNA) is incorrect because prokaryotes have DNA in the nucleoid region. Option B (ribosomes) is incorrect because both cell types have ribosomes (70S in prokaryotes, 80S in eukaryotes). Option D (cell membrane) is incorrect because all cells have a cell membrane. Only eukaryotes have a true, membrane-bound nucleus.

2. C ‚Äî Bacteria and archaea. These are the two domains of prokaryotic life. Option A is incorrect because plants and fungi are eukaryotes. Option B is incorrect because animals and protists are eukaryotes. Option D is incorrect because fungi are eukaryotes.

3. C ‚Äî Circular DNA and 70S ribosomes like bacteria. This directly links mitochondria to prokaryotic ancestry. Option A doesn't support endosymbiotic theory (presence in all eukaryotes just means they're important). Option B describes function, not origin. Option D is factually incorrect‚Äîmitochondria are similar in size to bacteria, not larger.

4. B ‚Äî Allows incompatible processes to occur simultaneously. For example, lysosomes can digest proteins while ribosomes synthesise proteins elsewhere in the cell. Option A is incorrect‚Äîcompartmentalisation allows cells to be larger, not smaller. Option C makes no sense‚ÄîDNA replication is still necessary. Option D is wrong‚Äîcells with organelles do divide.

5. B ‚Äî 2 billion years ago. Prokaryotes appeared 3.5 billion years ago, eukaryotes 2 billion years ago, multicellular organisms 1 billion years ago. The 500-million-year mark corresponds to the Cambrian explosion of animal diversity, not the origin of eukaryotes.

üìù SHORT ANSWER

Q6 (3 marks):

Difference 1: Prokaryotic cells lack a membrane-bound nucleus; their DNA is located in a nucleoid region in the cytoplasm. Eukaryotic cells have a true nucleus surrounded by a double membrane (nuclear envelope) that separates DNA from the cytoplasm. (1 mark)

Difference 2: Prokaryotic cells have no membrane-bound organelles. Eukaryotic cells contain multiple membrane-bound organelles including mitochondria, endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi apparatus, and lysosomes, which compartmentalise cellular functions. (1 mark)

Difference 3: Prokaryotic cells are much smaller (typically 0.1‚Äì5 Œºm diameter) than eukaryotic cells (typically 10‚Äì100 Œºm diameter)‚Äîup to 100 times smaller by volume. (1 mark)

Q7 (4 marks):

Theory description: The endosymbiotic theory proposes that mitochondria originated approximately 2 billion years ago when a large anaerobic prokaryotic cell engulfed a smaller aerobic prokaryote (likely an alpha-proteobacterium). Instead of digesting this engulfed cell, a stable symbiotic relationship formed where the smaller cell provided ATP through aerobic respiration, and the host provided protection and nutrients. Over millions of years, this relationship became obligate, with many genes transferring from the endosymbiont to the host nucleus, creating a permanent organelle. (2 marks)

Evidence 1: Mitochondria have double membranes‚Äîthe inner membrane from the original prokaryotic cell and the outer membrane from the host cell's engulfing vesicle during endocytosis. (1 mark)

Evidence 2: Mitochondria contain their own circular DNA molecules, similar to bacterial chromosomes, rather than the linear chromosomes found in eukaryotic nuclei. Additionally, they have 70S ribosomes (prokaryotic-type) rather than 80S ribosomes (eukaryotic-type). (1 mark)

Q8 (5 marks):

Advantage 1 ‚Äî Separation of incompatible processes: Lysosomes contain powerful digestive enzymes (proteases, lipases, nucleases) that would destroy cellular components if released into the cytoplasm. The lysosomal membrane isolates these enzymes, allowing safe breakdown of old organelles, engulfed pathogens, and cellular waste without damaging the rest of the cell. This compartmentalisation means destructive and constructive processes (like protein degradation in lysosomes versus protein synthesis at ribosomes) can occur simultaneously without interference. (2 marks)

Advantage 2 ‚Äî Optimised microenvironments for specialised reactions: Mitochondria can maintain specific internal conditions optimal for cellular respiration. The intermembrane space maintains a low pH (high H‚Å∫ concentration) while the matrix has a higher pH. This pH gradient across the inner mitochondrial membrane drives ATP synthase to produce ATP efficiently. Additionally, the highly folded inner membrane (cristae) increases surface area by 5‚Äì10 times, dramatically increasing the space available for electron transport chain proteins and ATP production. Without this membrane-bound compartment, these optimised conditions couldn't be maintained, and energy production would be far less efficient. (3 marks: 1 for identifying mitochondria, 1 for explaining optimised conditions/pH gradient, 1 for explaining increased efficiency through cristae/surface area)

activities.title: Classify Cell Features ‚Äî Answer Key
activities.keyPoint: The critical distinction is membrane-bound organelles‚Äîprokaryotes have NONE, eukaryotes have many. Both cell types share fundamental features like DNA, ribosomes, and cell membranes.

activities.title: Match Organelles to Functions ‚Äî Answer Key

answers.label: Nucleus ‚Üí Stores DNA and controls cell activities
answers.description: The nucleus is enclosed by a double membrane (nuclear envelope) with pores that regulate transport of molecules in and out.

answers.label: Mitochondria ‚Üí Cellular respiration and ATP production
answers.description: Often called the 'powerhouse of the cell'. Has its own DNA and 70S ribosomes (evidence for endosymbiotic theory).

answers.label: Endoplasmic reticulum ‚Üí Protein and lipid synthesis and transport
answers.description: Rough ER (with ribosomes) makes proteins; smooth ER synthesises lipids and detoxifies substances.

answers.label: Golgi apparatus ‚Üí Processes and packages proteins for export
answers.description: Receives proteins from the ER, modifies them (e.g. adds sugar groups), and packages them in vesicles for secretion.

answers.label: Lysosomes ‚Üí Digests waste and old organelles
answers.description: Contains powerful digestive enzymes at low pH. The membrane prevents these enzymes from damaging the rest of the cell.

answers.label: Chloroplasts ‚Üí Photosynthesis in plant cells and algae
answers.description: Has its own DNA and 70S ribosomes. Contains chlorophyll in thylakoid membranes. Also evidence for endosymbiotic theory.

activities.title: Sequence: How Endosymbiosis Created Mitochondria ‚Äî Answer Key
correctOrder: Large anaerobic prokaryote engulfs smaller aerobic prokaryote
Engulfed cell survives inside host, enclosed by membrane vesicle
Engulfed cell performs aerobic respiration, producing ATP for the host
Symbiotic relationship becomes obligate over millions of years
Genes transfer from endosymbiont to host nucleus
Engulfed cell becomes a mitochondrion with double membrane, own DNA, and 70S ribosomes
activities.explanation: This process took millions of years. The key insight is that the double membrane of mitochondria results from this engulfing event: the inner membrane is the original prokaryote's membrane, the outer membrane is the host's vesicle membrane.

activities.title: Match Endosymbiotic Evidence to Explanation ‚Äî Answer Key

answers.label: Double membrane ‚Üí Inner from original prokaryote, outer from host's engulfing vesicle
answers.description: This is exactly what we'd expect if one cell was engulfed by another through endocytosis.

answers.label: Own circular DNA ‚Üí Circular DNA is characteristic of prokaryotes, not eukaryotic nuclear DNA
answers.description: Eukaryotic nuclear DNA is linear. The circular DNA in mitochondria mirrors prokaryotic chromosomes.

answers.label: 70S ribosomes ‚Üí Prokaryotic ribosome size, not the 80S found in eukaryotic cytoplasm
answers.description: This is why some antibiotics target 70S ribosomes can affect mitochondrial function as a side effect.

answers.label: Divide by binary fission ‚Üí Binary fission is how prokaryotes reproduce, not typical of eukaryotic organelles
answers.description: Mitochondria replicate independently of the cell cycle, just as free-living bacteria would.

answers.label: DNA sequence similarity to bacteria ‚Üí Molecular phylogeny links organelles directly to specific bacterial groups
answers.description: Mitochondrial DNA closely resembles alpha-proteobacteria; chloroplast DNA resembles cyanobacteria.

assessment.question: Which feature is found in eukaryotic cells but NOT in prokaryotic cells?
assessment.explanation: Both cell types have DNA (A), ribosomes (B), and cell membranes (D). Only eukaryotes have a true, membrane-bound nucleus. Prokaryotes have a nucleoid region with no membrane.

assessment.question: Which group consists entirely of prokaryotic organisms?
assessment.explanation: Bacteria and archaea are the two domains of prokaryotic life. Plants, fungi (A, D), animals, and protists (B) are all eukaryotes.

assessment.question: Which statement about mitochondria provides the STRONGEST evidence for endosymbiotic theory?
assessment.correctAnswer: C ‚Äî Mitochondria have their own circular DNA and 70S ribosomes, like bacteria.
assessment.explanation: Circular DNA and 70S ribosomes directly link mitochondria to prokaryotic ancestry. Option A (presence in all eukaryotes) doesn't support origin theory. Option B (function) doesn't address origin. Option D is factually incorrect.

assessment.question: What is a major advantage of compartmentalisation in eukaryotic cells?
assessment.correctAnswer: B ‚Äî It allows incompatible chemical processes to occur simultaneously in different locations.
assessment.explanation: Compartmentalisation lets destructive processes (lysosomes) and constructive processes (ribosomes) happen simultaneously without interference.

assessment.question: Approximately when did eukaryotic cells first evolve?
assessment.explanation: Prokaryotes appeared ~3.5 billion years ago (A), eukaryotes ~2 billion years ago (B), multicellular organisms ~1 billion years ago (C). 500 million years ago (D) was the Cambrian explosion.

assessment.question: List and explain three structural differences between prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells.
assessment.correctAnswer: Difference 1: Prokaryotic cells lack a membrane-bound nucleus; their DNA is in a nucleoid region. Eukaryotic cells have a true nucleus with a double membrane (1 mark). Difference 2: Prokaryotes have no membrane-bound organelles. Eukaryotes have mitochondria, ER, Golgi, lysosomes, etc. (1 mark). Difference 3: Prokaryotes are smaller (0.1‚Äì5 Œºm) than eukaryotes (10‚Äì100 Œºm) (1 mark).

assessment.question: Describe the endosymbiotic theory for the origin of mitochondria. Include two pieces of evidence.
assessment.correctAnswer: A large anaerobic prokaryote engulfed a smaller aerobic prokaryote (1 mark). A stable symbiotic relationship formed‚Äîengulfed cell provided ATP through aerobic respiration, host provided protection and nutrients. Over millions of years, this became obligate with genes transferring to the host nucleus (1 mark). Evidence 1: Mitochondria have double membranes‚Äîinner from the original prokaryote, outer from the host's vesicle (1 mark). Evidence 2: Mitochondria have their own circular DNA and 70S ribosomes, both characteristic of prokaryotes rather than eukaryotes (1 mark).

assessment.question: Explain two advantages that membrane-bound organelles provide to eukaryotic cells.
assessment.correctAnswer: Advantage 1‚ÄîSeparation of incompatible processes: Lysosomes contain powerful digestive enzymes (proteases, lipases) that would destroy the cell if released. The lysosomal membrane isolates these enzymes, allowing safe digestion of waste while protein synthesis occurs elsewhere (2 marks). Advantage 2‚ÄîOptimised microenvironments: Mitochondria maintain a specific pH gradient across their inner membrane that drives ATP synthase. The highly folded inner membrane (cristae) increases surface area by 5‚Äì10 times, dramatically increasing ATP production efficiency. Without this compartment, these optimal conditions could not be maintained (3 marks).

definitions: Prokaryotic cell: A cell with no membrane-bound nucleus or organelles (e.g. bacteria, archaea).
Eukaryotic cell: A cell with a membrane-bound nucleus and membrane-bound organelles (e.g. animals, plants, fungi).
Nucleoid region: The area in a prokaryotic cell where circular DNA is concentrated, with no surrounding membrane.
Endosymbiotic theory: The theory that mitochondria and chloroplasts originated from prokaryotic cells engulfed by a larger host cell.
Compartmentalisation: The division of a eukaryotic cell into membrane-bound compartments (organelles), allowing incompatible chemical reactions to occur simultaneously.
Mitochondria: Double-membraned organelles that carry out cellular respiration and produce ATP; have their own circular DNA and 70S ribosomes.
Chloroplast: Double-membraned organelle found in plant cells and algae that carries out photosynthesis; also has its own DNA and 70S ribosomes.
keyPoints: Prokaryotes: no nucleus, no membrane-bound organelles, circular DNA, 70S ribosomes, 0.1‚Äì5 Œºm
Eukaryotes: membrane-bound nucleus, membrane-bound organelles, linear chromosomes with histones, 80S ribosomes, 10‚Äì100 Œºm
Key organelles: nucleus, mitochondria, ER, Golgi apparatus, lysosomes, chloroplasts (plants)
Endosymbiotic evidence: double membrane, own circular DNA, 70S ribosomes, binary fission, DNA similarity to bacteria
Prokaryotes appeared ~3.5 billion years ago; eukaryotes ~2 billion years ago
